messages: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:21): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I assume you failing the html5lib tests like <!DOCTYPE html><p><b><i><u></p> <p>X is deliberate? Do you have a bug for the spec change you anticipate?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:34): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: the test that fail due to space character interaction of space characters with formatting elements are known
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:35): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: and deferring fixing is deliberate
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:36): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: You consider it a bug in the spec or in gecko?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:36): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: whether the failure itself should be considered deliberate isn't quite so clear to me, but I tend to think that it'd bad to make "in body" sensitive to spaceness
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:36): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I consider it a bug in Gecko, but more careful thinking might persuade me to consider it a bug in the spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:37): I think how forcefully I will consider it a spec bug will depend on performance metrics that I don't have at this time

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:38): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: OK, thanks. Maybe we should have a list on a wiki page or something of possible issues? I seem to recall that there were some other things that you considered bugs in the spec?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:39): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: the other spec bugs are on file
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Is there a list somewhere?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:40): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: except I think Hixie avoided fixing one bug I had filed before and I should take the time to repursue
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:40): (that was about freezing src, async and defer)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:41): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: you get a list if you search for bugs reported by <email/> in the W3C bugzilla
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:44): the src, async defer thing is only detectable if you document.write a script start tag, then use the DOM to modify the element and then write the end tag
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:49): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: but yeah, we should probably have a wiki page
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: any ideas for the title? "Possible bugs in the HTML5 parsing algorithm according to b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9"? :-)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/ParserIssues
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:51): Does that list seem complete
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:52): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I'm adding the missing bits

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:13): anyone know what‚Äôs up with HTML5 + ARIA? Wasn‚Äôt there a combo spec? I found Mike‚Äôs H:TML (ARIA edition) but it‚Äôs Sept 2009, so I‚Äôm guessing not being updated‚Ä¶

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:17): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/content-models.html#annotations-for-assistive-technology-products-%28aria%29
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:18): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: so ARIA still lives in its own specs and HTML5 references those
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: aah, naruhodo. Yeah I‚Äôd found that, but obviously needed to read the first sentence more thoroughly
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:19): AT is a rather sad state of affairs. Luckily NVDA is eating their lunch so they‚Äôll be forced to evolve or die
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:21): couldn‚Äôt believe the attitude of Window-Eyes devs; ‚Äòspec not finished so not worth our time til then‚Äô O_o
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:21): doesn‚Äôt help that they have major bugs with new elements + landmark roles either
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:22): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: "spec" being ARIA or HTML5?
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:23): oh, is ARIA not doe either? har! well I guess that reasoning means they don‚Äôt really need to support anything then

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:26): ‚ÄúNot only is HTML5 still in draft, there are parts of ARIA that are sill not completely set in stone. This is another reason why providing some sort of release time frame is difficult; the technologies are a moving target‚Äù http://www.mail-archive.com/<email/>/msg10851.html
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (14:27): so they appear to be waiting, although not until 2022 it seems
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:30): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: I guess they haven't gotten the memo about the interdependency of spec maturity and implementations
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I did some hacking to the v.nu datatype code today in an attempt to improve error-reporting for IRIs a bit
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:32): current results: http://www.w3.org/html/check?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fbugzilla.validator.nu%2Fattachment.cgi%3Fid%3D177
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:33): compare to current source: http://validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fbugzilla.validator.nu%2Fattachment.cgi%3Fid%3D177
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:33): trying to make the messages a little more user friendly
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:34): e.g., instead of "DNS_LABEL_DASH_START_OR_END in HOST", "Host component contains a DNS name with a - (dash) character at the beginning or end."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:36): along the way, discovered a couple of other IRI-checking cases that it seems like should be reported as warnings instead of errors
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:36): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: that's great!
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:37): I think there's probably a few cases I missed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:37): but anyway, for those cases, it'll just fall back to reporting them the same way as the existing code
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:38): anyway, will send you a patch after I test it some more
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:38): and maybe if I can get zcorpan_ to throw some other test cases at it
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:39): about the Jing patch: I need to check what kind of copyright bureaucracy the project requires (if any) before I land the patch
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:40): no rush, anyway

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:41): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 I take it that you are contributing the Jing patch the same way as other V.nu patches, i.e. under the same license as the file being patched and waiving notices?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:42): I guess that was supposed to be a DM
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:42): good thing you didn't reveal any secrets of the inner cabal there
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:42): anyway, yeah, same terms as always
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:42): you guys keeping secrets? ooh
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:45): There are no secrets... that you know of

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:45): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: plus remember the blood-brother ceremony

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:46): this time the changes to named character references in attribute values

58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (15:14): http://twitter.com/big_ben_CLOCK
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:14): Localization is important
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (15:14): but yeah, the idea is quite.. original
0c25ae3066f1b9f7890ceff405fdcab1 (15:14): see also http://twitter.com/NotreDameDParis
0c25ae3066f1b9f7890ceff405fdcab1 (15:14): actually: http://twitter.com/memowe/kirchen-die-twittern
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:15): great
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:25): Awesome. Now all we need is someone to implement NTP over Twitter. :-)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:25): ... or Twitter Time Protocol
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:31): I guess you could get second precision via twitter, which is enough for normal human use

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:43): I'm not sure you could even get that level of precision any more. It may have been possible when they were sending out tweets in near real time when they had Jabber support.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:44): But I don't think it's possible with the current API setup that, AIUI, needs to be done by the client polling twitter for updates at regular intervals.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:58): Surely you could just use a timestamp from an HTTP header in the response from the Twitter API, instead of looking in the actual tweet to work out the time
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:58): or would that be considered an unacceptable layering violation?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:59): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: The server isn't required to return the right value
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:01): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: It's even less required to return the right value in the response body
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Presumably the contents of the response body count as application-level semantics
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:02): It's true that twitter doesn't make any promises
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:02): So using twitter for time would probably be a bad idea
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:03): The inefficiency of twitter for this purpose doesn't seem to stop people from trying http://twitter.com/CurrentTime
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:04): The inefficiency of twitter for any and all communications doesn't stop people trying
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:15): I guess now my only excuse for not making a release of the V.nu parser is the 8000 byte limit
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:16): so it will be slow unless run with a special VM switch
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:16): I wonder if I should make a release anyway or develop a workaround...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:17): I guess I should develop a workaround...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:25): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I redeployed V.nu without your recently landed patches and mine
